facts.text: Respondents are owners of the land in village Kasarkhed, District Akola.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the owners of the land in question situate in the village Kasarkhed, District Akola.

facts.text: Floods in 1959 affected residents living in gaothan of Kasarkhed.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1959 there were floods in the are which affected the resident living in the gaothan of Kasarkhed.

facts.text: Floods in 1961 more serious than 1959 affecting 470 persons whose houses were washed away or seriously damaged.

anchor.surface_text: Once again there were floods in 1961 more serious than in 1959 affecting as many as 470 persons whose houses were either washed away or seriously damaged.

facts.text: Urgent necessity to rehabilitate flood sufferers at another place before next monsoon.

concepts.interpretation: Power to requisition any land for any public purpose without express limitation to temporary purposes; only limitation is public purpose and temporary life of the Act.
concepts.unlisted_description: Authorizes State Government to requisition any land by order if necessary or expedient for any public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the first appellant under powers conferred on him by section 15 of the Act passed the impugned order.
In the return filed by the appellants these allegations were -traversed and it was submitted that the order was valid and competent under sec- tion 5 1  of the Act.

Section 5 1  under which the impugned order was made provides that if in the opinion of the State Government it is necessary or expedient so to do the State Government may by an order in writing requisition any land for any public purpose.

concepts.interpretation: Only requirement is opinion of necessity or expediency for public purpose; no express or implied limitation to temporary purpose.

arguments.claim: Section 5(1) authorizes requisition of any land for any public purpose without limitation to temporary purposes

arguments.claim: No implied restriction in s.5(1) that purpose must be temporary
Temporary life of Act does not imply temporary purpose; words 'any land for any public purpose' wide enough
Section 9 on derequisition does not limit nature of purpose under s.5(1)
No antithesis between requisition power and acquisition power; can follow requisition with acquisition
Initiation of Land Acquisition Act proceedings after requisition does not indicate abuse

holdings.text: The words 'any land for any public purpose' in section 5(1) are sufficiently wide enough to include any public purpose whether temporary or otherwise
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of section 5(1) shows no limitation on purpose beyond public purpose; temporary life of Act does not restrict purpose to temporary

holdings.text: Section 5(1) does not contain by implication any restriction that the requisitioning authority has no power to pass an order where the purpose is not temporary

anchor.surface_text: The question then is does the sub- section contain by implication any restriction viz., that the requisitioning authority has no power thereunder to pass an order where the purpose is not temporary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express or implied limitation in text of section 5(1) to temporary purposes only

holdings.text: Section 9 has nothing to do with the nature or character of the purpose for which an order under section 5(1) is passed
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 9 deals with restoration upon derequisition, independent of purpose character under section 5(1)

holdings.text: There is no antithesis between the power to requisition and the power of compulsory acquisition under the Land Acquisition Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory bar to exercising requisition followed by acquisition; Part VI of LAA allows temporary occupation

holdings.text: The initiation of proceedings under the Land Acquisition Act after requisitioning the lands under section 5(1) does not and cannot mean abuse of the power under the provisions of the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sequential use of powers compatible and not abusive

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in holding that the power to requisition under the Act cannot be exercised where the public purpose is not temporary or that the exercise of that power for the purposes of rehabilitation of flood sufferers was either in abuse of or unjustified under the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's interpretation limiting power to temporary purposes and finding abuse

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order passed by the High Court. Since the High Court decided the petition only on the question of the validity of the exercise of power and did number decide the other questions raised in the petition,

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order quashing the requisition order set aside; matter remanded to High Court for deciding other issues raised in the petition
directions: remand the matter to the High Court to decide those questions in accordance with law
